text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.35.4, Financial Accounting, Purchase Card Program.
IRM 1.35.4.1.3.2, Chief Procurement Officer and Office of Procurement Policy, added responsibility for Chief Procurement Officer.
1.35.4.1.3.5, Purchase Cardholders, the changes include the following:

a. Removed responsibility to forward receipts to the PC approving official b. Added the requirement to attach documentation relating to activity on the PC to the Purchase Card Module order log c. Added additional responsibilities for the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) Section
and Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS).

IRM 1.35.4.1.6, Terms/Deﬁnitions, removed the deﬁnition for Chip and personal identiﬁcation number (PIN) enabled cards and Merchant; added the deﬁnition for Certiﬁcate of Appointment; updated the deﬁnition for Purchase Card Module and Purchase Card Electronic Retention (PCEDR).
IRM 1.35.4.1.7, Acronyms, updated acronyms.

IRM 1.35.4.1.9.2, Purchase Card Criteria for PC Approving Officials, removed responsibility to provide copies of documentation timely for inactive purchase cardholders when requested by officials performing reviews and audits unless maintained in the PCDER SharePoint site from list.
IRM 1.35.4.3.2, Unauthorized Purchase Card Use, added the following to the list of unauthorized purchase card use: NDAA Section 889 certiﬁcation requirements not met for open market vendors.

IRM 1.35.4.3.6, Separation of Duties and PC Approving Official Span of Control, revised bullet d to clarify a PC approving official cannot be a subordinate (organizationally) to a cardholder unless an exception is granted by Credit Card Services.
IRM 1.35.4.3.9, Required Sources for Micro-Purchases, removed Office Supply Program for IRS Desk Guide link because it is no longer an available resource.
IRM 1.35.4.5.1, Purchase Card/Convenience Check Training, updated the PC training requirements table.

Appendix B to OMB Circular A-123, Improving the Management of Govern- ment Charge Card Programs, mandates agencies to have internal controls that include standard minimum requirements for the issuance and retention of a PC to reduce the administrative costs associated with the government PC.

a. Authorization - The process undertaken by a vendor to verify that a purchase is allowable on a particular purchase cardholder account. Vendors sometimes seek authorization if a purchase exceeds certain dollar limits (e.g., $
or $
). When a vendor seeks authorization for a purchase, the Maste
ard authorization system will compare the proposed transaction with the limitations placed on the purchase card- holder’s account. b. Billing cycle - The period of time commencing on the
th of each month and ending on the

rd of the following month. All transactions that post an account during a billing cycle are summarized on a statement of account. c. Bulk (or “block”) funding - A method of setting aside funds for multiple purchases that may be shared by multiple purchase cardholders. Bulk funding eliminates the requirement for a separate requisition for each purchase. Funds for a general type expense, such as basic desktop office supplies, are approved and funded for purchase in advance. Bulk funding does not eliminate the requirement that purchases must be approved prior to using the PC.

d. Card limit - The maximum cumulative amount that can be charged to a PC in any one billing cycle. The PC limits are used to strengthen internal controls by establishing the appropriate amount a purchase cardholder can spend in a billing cycle to accomplish their program responsibilities. e. Certiﬁcate of Appointment - A SF

is used for appointing contract- ing officers and is required for procurement authority exceeding the micro-purchase threshold. f. Convenience check - An alternative form of payment associated with a PC account limited to $
for goods/services and $

for construc- tion/alterations. Convenience checks can only be used where the vendor does not accept the PC or other methods of payment cannot be used and the request is for safety, security and/or enforcement. g. Delegation of Procurement Authority (DPA) - A written DPA is required for micro-purchase authority (i.e. governmentwide commercial purchase cardholder, convenience check holder). An individual DPA issued to a micro-purchase cardholder through the Integrated Talent Management (ITM) providing their card limits and scope of purchasing authority. Purchase cardholders are required to acknowledge their indi- vidual DPA through the ITM system. h. Disputed item - An erroneous, duplicate or over charge that appears as a transaction on an individually billed government purchase cardholder’s statement of account or on the transaction screen in the Purchase Card Module. i. Merchant category code (MCC) - A standard code assigned to every vendor that accepts a credit card that identiﬁes the category of goods, services or activity they are involved with. The accuracy of the assigned MCC is the function of the vendor and Maste

ard. j. Merchant category code (MCC) template - A grouping of codes that are assigned to each purchase cardholder’s account based on their anticipated purchasing activity. An MCC template is an element of the system of internal controls for the credit card program, helping to reduce the potential for inappropriate use of a PC. k. Micro-purchase - An acquisition of supplies with an aggregate (total cost of purchase determined by total need) purchase amount that does not exceed $
for services; $

for construction). l. Purchase Card Module - A customized system developed alongside IFS to provide the purchase cardholder the ability to electronically fund, associate, reconcile and monitor purchase card transactions. This system enhances internal controls and ensures timely posting of obligations and payments to the ﬁnancial system. m. Purchase card (PC) - The credit card used to purchase goods and services for IRS official government use only. n. Purchase card (PC) approving official - An individual with oversight and approval responsibility for PC activity of the purchase cardholders under his or her purview. o. Purchase card (PC) approving official designee - A PC approving official who is designated to approve another PC approving official’s card- holders’ transactions in the Purchase Card Module. Designation as an acting manager does not confer authority to act as PC approving official. The designee must be from the same business unit as the PC approving official and must be a PC approving official for a group of purchase card- holders. Program

q. PC reference document - The PC reference document is a tool which assists purchase cardholders with determining if a PC may be used to make support-type purchases. r. Purchase cardholder - An IRS employee who has been given a Delega- tion of Procurement Authority (DPA) and is authorized to make purchases using the PC. The purchase cardholder is the only user of the PC and is responsible for safeguarding the PC and account number to minimize the opportunity for theft or unauthorized use. s. Required sources - Vendors deemed by FAR Part

as prioritized required sources for supplies and services. t. Restricted Purchase List - Written guidance with a list of goods and services that IRS employees are prohibited from purchasing or items that can only be purchased with the appropriate approvals. The Restricted Purchase List is maintained by the Office of Procurement Policy. u. Single transaction limit - The PC dollar limit for any one transaction. maximum allowable micro-purchase single transaction limit is $
for services; $

for construction/alterations). The maximum allowable single transaction limit applies to all purchase cardholders except those with contracting warrants. v. Split purchase - A series of purchases from the same vendor on the day in a total amount that exceeds his/her single transaction limit ($
goods, $
for services and $

for construction). A purchase card- holder may not make a split purchase under any circumstances. w. Statement of account - A summary of transactions (debits and credits) posted to the purchase cardholder’s account during the billing cycle. x. Tax exemption - PC purchases made and paid directly by the federal ernment are tax exempt where the government is responsible for the payment. Purchase cardholders can access the tax exemption letter for states and commonwealths prior to conducting official business. y. Vendor - The source of goods or services purchased. The vendor can be an individual or any type of business entity. (

Have a business need for the PC by making an average of four purchases per ﬁscal year. Create a PC order log in the Purchase Card Module for the items to be purchased and must associate a proper, fully funded requisition prior to placing an order. business days of the transaction download date. Document receipt of goods/services for all posted transactions and input the receipt date in the Purchase Card Module. Use the Purchase Card Module order log to attach the appropriate docu- mentation to support each purchase.

Have a minimum of one assigned purchase cardholder. Not be a purchase cardholder or plan manager. Be in the same business unit as the purchase cardholder unless an agreement for one business unit to perform PC approving official duties of another business unit is established. Be the same or higher grade and not subordinate organizationally to the assigned purchase cardholder(s). Review downloaded transactions in the Purchase Card Module and purchase cardholder documentation to ensure adherence to guidelines and that the appropriate approvals, funding and documentation exist to support each purchase.

) The Purchase Card Module enhances internal controls and ensures timely posting of obligations and payments to the ﬁnancial system. Purchase card- holders have the ability to electronically fund, associate, reconcile and purchase card transactions in the Purchase Card Module.
) Purchase Card Order (
) Purchase cardholders must create and add a funded requisition to a PC log prior to making a purchase. The PC order log tracks each step of a purchase and documents transaction details. (
) When goods or services are received, the PC order log item received date ﬁeld must be updated.
) Processing Time Frames (
) Purchase cardholders must associate/reconcile and PC approving officials must approve transactions within
business days of the transaction download date in the Purchase Card Module. (

) In the absence of the purchase cardholder, the PC approving official must review, associate and approve transactions.
